Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Adhere to professional standards and operational protocols.
Situation2: A mandatory pre-shift briefing on new operational procedures is about to start.
Story: I stared at my phone, my mother’s message glowing on the screen: “We need you to lead the ceremony tonight. It means so much to your father.” My heart thudded. This ceremony wasn’t just a family gathering—it was a tradition, a thread tying us to our roots. I knew how much it mattered, how proud my parents would be if I stepped up. But as I glanced at the clock, my chest tightened. My shift as a subway operator started soon, and today was the mandatory pre-shift briefing on new safety protocols. Missing it wasn’t an option; the company was strict, and I’d be letting my team down. My supervisor’s words echoed in my mind: “We need everyone on board with these changes.” I felt pulled in two directions—my family’s expectations weighing on one side, my professional duty on the other. I could almost hear my father’s voice, full of hope, and my supervisor’s, full of urgency. My hands trembled as I tried to figure out how to be the son my family needed and the operator my job demanded.
